Goals.
At the hands of the Mount Washington Club, the Johns HopkinsAlumni Lacrosse Team met its first defeat
of the season on Saturday afternoon
by the score of 3 to 0.
Considering the handicaps which
the alumni were under they deserve
ci edit for keeping the score as low
as it was. Walter Blanck at goal
displayed his old-time form and blocked a number of good goals. Fred
Blanck, the "Schmeisser Twins," and
Micky Erlanger also played well for
Hopkins.
Chesney and Lowndes were out of
the game, and their loss was heavily
felt by the alumni. Mengel, the
Straus duet, and Wright formed an
attack which was quite inadequate,
and which could hardly get a shot
at goal.
Mathais was the star or Mt. Washington, scoring all three of their
goals. Two of these were in the first
half.
Shortly after the game started,
Blanck and Hudgins collided. The
latter managed, however, to roll the
ball to Mathais, who drew first blood
for Mt. Washington.
The next goal was made on a beautiful pass from Matthai to Mathais,
who again got one past "Bock"
Blanck.
Five minutes after the second half
began Mathais again got the ball and
bored in close enough to get a high
one into the net.
Mt. Washington—Briscoe (capt.),
goal; Lamotte, point; Stonecipher,
cover point; Pearre, first defense;
Lawton, Price, second defense; Harrison, third defense; Lamb, center;

Special to The News-Letter.
South Bethlehem, Pa., May 1—
By brilliant all-round play the Hopkins lacrosse team won a hard fought
game from the Lehigh twelve last
Saturday afternoon at South Bethlehem by the score of 6 to 3. The black
and blue attack, which seemed too
light at the beginning of the season,
covered itself with glory. Stockett,
Hulburt, Gail and Wolfe ran circles
about their heavier opponents. Clary
did not figure in the game as much
as usual, as the Lehigh twelve were
taught by last year's game that he
was a dangerous man, and Donaldson, the losers' crack defense player,
stuck beside throughout the whole
contest.
Stockett shot five goals in the first
half. The Lehigh defense was in a
bewildered state for a time, as a result of the speed of the Hopkins attack. Near the end of the half the
Pennsylvanians braced up considerably. Rowan, the Baltimore boy who
is playing outhome for Lehigh, shot
their first goal. The half ended with
the score five to one.
The Hopkins players took no chances in the second half and played on

"WHY DOGS LEAVE HOME"
Billy Haynes Gives An Interesting Lecture on This Most Important Topic.
At the last meeting of the Naturalists Field Club of the Johns Hopkins
University, Mr. N. Williams Haynes,
the well known dog fancier and
sophomore president, gave a most interesting lecture on dog breeding. He
discussed the various methods of
breeding and pointed out the particular advantages of each one. He explained the method of writing out a
dog's pedigree. A number of photographs of various kind of dogs had
been specially collected by the lecturer to illustrate some of the points
he wished to bring out. Mr. Haynes
imitated the barking of dogs most
realistically. A number of questions
were asked by those present and
were answered to the satisfaction of
everybody.

At the hands of the Mount Washington Club, the Johns HopkinsAlumni Lacrosse Team met its first defeat
of the season on Saturday afternoon
by the score of 3 to 0.
Considering the handicaps which
the alumni were under they deserve
ci edit for keeping the score as low
as it was. Walter Blanck at goal
displayed his old-time form and blocked a number of good goals. Fred
Blanck, the "Schmeisser Twins," and
Micky Erlanger also played well for
Hopkins.
Chesney and Lowndes were out of
the game, and their loss was heavily
felt by the alumni. Mengel, the
Straus duet, and Wright formed an
attack which was quite inadequate,
and which could hardly get a shot
at goal.
Mathais was the star or Mt. Washington, scoring all three of their
goals. Two of these were in the first
half.
Shortly after the game started,
Blanck and Hudgins collided. The
latter managed, however, to roll the
ball to Mathais, who drew first blood
for Mt. Washington.
The next goal was made on a beautiful pass from Matthai to Mathais,
who again got one past "Bock"
Blanck.
Five minutes after the second half
began Mathais again got the ball and
bored in close enough to get a high
one into the net.
Mt. Washington—Briscoe (capt.),
goal; Lamotte, point; Stonecipher,
cover point; Pearre, first defense;
Lawton, Price, second defense; Harrison, third defense; Lamb, center;
Breyer, third attack; Hudgins, second
attack; Armstrong, first attack; Mathias, out home; Matthai, in home.
Hopkins Alumni—W. Blanck, goal;
W. Schmeisser (capt.), point; H.
Schmeisser, cover point; F. Blanck,
first defense; Meyer, second defense;
Erlanger, third defense; Gutman,center ; Abercrombie, third attack; Mengel, second attack; T. Straus, first attack; Wright, out home; H. Straus,
in home.
Goals—Mathias for Mt. Washington, 3. Referee, Robert Lowndes ;
umpires, Messrs. Clark and Mac
Crowe: timers, Messrs. Baldwin and
Holmes.

Special to The News-Letter.
South Bethlehem, Pa., May 1—
By brilliant all-round play the Hopkins lacrosse team won a hard fought
game from the Lehigh twelve last
Saturday afternoon at South Bethlehem by the score of 6 to 3. The black
and blue attack, which seemed too
light at the beginning of the season,
covered itself with glory. Stockett,
Hulburt, Gail and Wolfe ran circles
about their heavier opponents. Clary
did not figure in the game as much
as usual, as the Lehigh twelve were
taught by last year's game that he
was a dangerous man, and Donaldson, the losers' crack defense player,
stuck beside throughout the whole
contest.
Stockett shot five goals in the first
half. The Lehigh defense was in a
bewildered state for a time, as a result of the speed of the Hopkins attack. Near the end of the half the
Pennsylvanians braced up considerably. Rowan, the Baltimore boy who
is playing outhome for Lehigh, shot
their first goal. The half ended with
the score five to one.
The Hopkins players took no chances in the second half and played on

"WHY DOGS LEAVE HOME"
Billy Haynes Gives An Interesting Lecture on This Most Important Topic.
At the last meeting of the Naturalists Field Club of the Johns Hopkins
University, Mr. N. Williams Haynes,
the well known dog fancier and
sophomore president, gave a most interesting lecture on dog breeding. He
discussed the various methods of
breeding and pointed out the particular advantages of each one. He explained the method of writing out a
dog's pedigree. A number of photographs of various kind of dogs had
been specially collected by the lecturer to illustrate some of the points
he wished to bring out. Mr. Haynes
imitated the barking of dogs most
realistically. A number of questions
were asked by those present and
were answered to the satisfaction of
everybody.
